articles.title: California firefighters save horse stuck in outdoor bathtub (APN)

articles.author: Bioethics Pundit
articles.summary:
(BBC) - Canada's Supreme Court has ruled that doctors may help patients who
have severe and incurable medical conditions to die, overturning a 1993 ban.
In a unanimous decision, the court said that the law impinged on Canadians'
rights.
articles.title: Canada to Allow Doctor-Assisted Suicide (bioethicscom)

articles.author: By DECLAN WALSH
articles.summary:
The High Court in Baluchistan has canceled all foreign permits to hunt the
houbara bustard in response to complaints from conservationists.
articles.title: For Saudis and Pakistan, a Bird of Contention (New York Times)

articles.summary:
The tropical plant Genlisea is a tiny, homely rosette of simple green leaves.
If you dig up its roots, you will find what look like an unremarkable bunch
long, pale underground roots.


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: For These Plants, No Victim Is Too Small (Scientific American)

articles.summary:
CHEYENNE, Wyo. (AP) -- Warm weather has helped grant a reprieve this year to a
homely, eel-like and especially slimy fish pursued by anglers as they compete
for big money in two annual ice-fishing tournaments at a reservoir on the
Wyoming-Utah line....
articles.title: Lack of ice hampers efforts to net homely invasive fish (The Arizona Republic)

articles.author: Ken Kremer
articles.summary:
The long awaited Deep Space Climate Observatory, or DSCOVR science satellite
is slated to blast off atop a SpaceX Falcon 9 on Sunday, Feb. 8, from Cape
Canaveral, Florida on a mission to monitor the solar wind and aid very
important forecasts of space weather at Earth. DSCOVR is a joint mission
between NOAA, NASA, […]
articles.title: NOAA/NASA/USAF Deep Space Climate Observatory (DSCOVR) Launching Feb. 8 to Monitor Solar Winds (Universe Today)

that was generally well-developed.
articles.title: Rare Case of Conjoined Lizard Twins Reported at Zoo (Discovery)

articles.summary:
I've always found gyms a bit strange. Think about it: Dozens of people
sweating in close proximity, running on conveyor belts going nowhere, lifting
and dropping heavy objects for no reason.

articles.title: Reducing Lifestyle Diseases Means Changing Our Environment (Scientific American)

articles.summary:
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (Reuters) - A SpaceX rocket is scheduled on Sunday to
launch a U.S. satellite from deep storage to deep space, where it will keep
tabs on solar storms and image Earth from nearly 1 million miles (1.6 million
km) away.
articles.title: SpaceX rocket to launch weather satellite into deep space (reuters)

articles.title: UN climate chief tempers expectation on Paris deal (co.nz)

articles.summary:
Editor's note: This is a guest post by Avery McGaha, one of two master’s
students who joined me in Tromsø, Norway to attend the Arctic Frontiers
conference in January, 2014. It is supplemented with some additional reporting
by me. McGaha's trip was made possible by a grant from the University of
Colorado's Center for Environmental Journalism.  Following the recent
announcement by NASA and NOAA that 2014 was likely the hottest year on record
a loud controversy erupted over global warming.
articles.title: Whispers of Ecological Change in the Arctic Are Trying to Tell Us Something. Are We Listening? (Discover Magazine)
